content:
New laws challenge America's church-state divide

AMERICA’S GOVERNMENT schools have long been used to set the contours of the First Amendment’s separation between church and state. In 1962, the Supreme Court ruled that organised prayer in school is unconstitutional. That decision was followed by bans on Bible reading in 1963, displays on the Ten Commandments in classrooms in 1980, religious moments of silence in 1985, graduation prayers in 1992 and student-led supplications at American football games in 2000. But in recent years, the justices have appeared more cautious. In 2004, they avoided answering whether the words “under God” in the Pledge of Allegiance run contrary to the prohibition on the “establishment of religion”.

With a president in the White House who is keen to please the conservative evangelicals who helped bring him to power, some Christian organisations on the right are motivated and mobilised. And with the advent of a solid conservative majority on the Supreme Court, Thomas Jefferson’s “wall of separation” between church and state is unlikely to be policed as closely as it was in the second half of the 20th century. 

A recent chink in the church-state wall may be seen in the hanging of “In God We Trust” placards inside government schools. When earlier this year Kimberly Davis, a Democratic legislator in Florida, introduced a bill to allow this, she said violence-prone schools “need light in them like never before”. In March, Florida's legislature passed a bill requiring “In God We Trust” to appear in each of the state’s government schools. Similar bills have recently mustered wide majorities in Alabama, Arkansas, Arizona, Louisiana and Tennessee. More may follow: North Carolina, South Carolina, Oklahoma and Pennsylvania will consider adopting “In God We Trust” bills in 2019.

Are these measures constitutional? Probably. “In God We Trust” has been the national motto since 1956, when Dwight D. Eisenhower signed H. J. Resolution 396; the phrase adorns American coins and bills and is found in courthouses around the country. Legal challenges to the phrase on the currency have been in vain. In 1970, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals noted that it is “quite obvious” the motto “has nothing whatsoever to do with the establishment of religion” and is merely “patriotic or ceremonial” in character. In August, the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals rejected a challenge to the slogan on coins and bank notes from a group of atheists. The motto is in line with America’s historical practices, the judges wrote, and the government “does not compel citizens to engage in a religious observance when it places the national motto on money”. It could be argued that putting up the words inside a school may violate students’ constitutional rights—the courts do take a stricter view of the Establishment Clause when it comes to children—but it is unlikely federal judges will undermine this opening salvo of evangelicals’ drive to sanctify public life in America.

Part of the push behind “In God We Trust” is a three-year-old endeavour dubbed “Project Blitz” that aims to instil “traditional Judeo-Christian religious values and beliefs in the public square, and to reclaim and properly define the narrative which supports such beliefs.” A joint effort of the Congressional Prayer Caucus Foundation; WallBuilders, which promotes the idea that America is a Christian country; and the National Legal Foundation, a group of Christian lawyers, Project Blitz calls the bills “national motto display acts”. Their success in reaching state legislators may be apparent in the text of Florida’s law, which requires “In God We Trust” to appear in a “conspicuous” spot in each school—language matching up that of the organisation's model legislation. Project Blitz's website boasts that of more than 200 “religious freedom” bills proposed in the states this year, “74 could be directly traced” to their 116-page report prepared a year ago.  

After exposing students to God on the walls of their schools, the groups aim to get them reading the Bible (via a “Bible Literacy Act”) and to consider “religious documents that have been instrumental in the development of law” in America (“Religion in Legal History Act”). It also offers sample legislation for states seeking to fight back against advances in the rights of gay, lesbian and transgender Americans, including measures to “favour sexual relations only between married, heterosexual couples”; to reinforce “birth gender”; and to prohibit gay and lesbian couples from adopting children.

The organisations pushing this agenda realise some of their proposals will “engender lively opposition”. They encourage state legislators to take care “to avoid bringing this legislation to a vote unless the vote can be won” as defeats “will put allies and leadership in a difficult position”. Project Blitz also says it is important to de-emphasise the “biblical” norms at the heart of these proposals. Better to frame them in terms of “measurable interests such as avoiding medical costs and the like” to inoculate the legislation against constitutional challenges.

It is unclear whether couching these proposals in secular terms would put them in a better light if they were adopted and then challenged in court. But with the imprint of Donald Trump’s judicial nominees on the Supreme Court and lower courts, it is increasingly likely that some of Project Blitz’s goals will pass muster in the coming years. The next sign of where the Supreme Court may stand on these questions will come in early 2019, when the justices ask whether a first world war memorial on public ground in the shape of a 40-foot cross squares with America's guarantee of religious liberty.

不同于《权利法案》的是，《第十四条修正案》专门针对州政府。
